info.game_comments:
2005 College Championship semifinal game 3.
From the RBC Center in Raleigh, North Carolina.

(1, 1).clue: Of the Monica, the Rachel or the Phoebe, the rescue ship at the tale's end

(2, 1).clue: To mark his 18th birthday in 2002, this prince visited the sick & homeless to carry on the work of his late mother

(3, 1).clue: KO the competition with this "Classic" soft drink company, symbol KO

(4, 1).clue: Installments of this controversial crime-based game include "San Andreas" & "Vice City"

(1, 2).clue: Melville's subtitle for the first American edition

(2, 2).clue: In 1996 he was "Livin' La Vida Loca" on Broadway, playing Marius in "Les Miz"

(3, 2).clue: For the ultimate in geek chic, get the TI-89 Titanium graphing calculator from this company, TXN

(4, 2).clue: In the '05 version of the EA title named for this ex-Raiders coach, Al Michaels does the play-by-play

(1, 3).clue: The harpooner from Kokovoko with the rad tats

(2, 3).clue: The website of this tennis "goddess" told us that she's 6'2", loves to write poetry & wants to go to Croatia

(3, 3).clue: Spokesman Jeff Gordon sprays the fastlane with Halston Z-14 from this company, RDEN

(4, 3).clue: In "God of War", PlayStation 2 lets you play Kratos, a Greek warrior whose final fight is with this Greek god of war

(1, 4).clue: Salem, Massachusetts author to whom the 1851 novel is dedicated

(2, 4).clue: Visitors to the Sundance Film Festival know that the Sundance Institute was founded by this man in 1981

(3, 4).clue: Buy books at this company, BKS, which also goes under the B. Dalton name

(4, 4).clue: It's Master Chief versus the Covenant in the first version of this Xbox game named for a ring-like space station

(1, 5).clue: The biblical prophet who's the subject of chapter 83

(2, 5).clue: He wore a kilt when he married Madonna in a Scottish castle

(3, 5).clue: Originally named Sound of Music, this company, BBY, still offers sound electronics & music

(4, 5).clue: This role-playing game out in 2004 returns to the "World" of Azeroth, where heroes like Leeroy Jenkins do battle

(1, 1).clue: Oskar Schindler is buried on Mount Zion in this city

(2, 1).clue: He's the funny man who played the title role in the movie version of "The Cat in the Hat"

(3, 1).clue: 1984:To this "physician", for his books of playful rhymes, nonsense words & strange illustrations

(4, 1).clue: This ditty about a pony-riding gentleman is Connecticut's state song

(5, 1).clue: Catch an express train to the Algarve from the Barreiro Station in this Iberian capital

(6, 1).clue: A cntrctd. form of a wd. or phrs., frm. the Ltn. for "shrtnd."

(1, 2).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew reads from outside a black brick edifice in Lubeck, Germany.)  The elaborate use of brick in Lubeck, Germany began early in the city's history, partially in response to this disaster in 1157

(2, 2).clue: This innovative Polish director brought Charles Dickens' "Oliver Twist" to life in 2005

(3, 2).clue: 1960:To Professor Garrett Mattingly, for his study of this 16th century Spanish fleet

(4, 2).clue: How sweet it is that this is North Carolina's official state insect

(5, 2).clue: President Harding drove the golden spike at Nenana for this state's RR & died on the way home

(6, 2).clue: Class of a pro boxer topping out at 160 pounds

(1, 3).clue: This capital's Plaza Independencia has a statue of Jose Artigas, hero of Uruguayan independencia

(2, 3).clue: "Zathura" is from a book by Chris Van Allsburg, author of this "cool" story, later a Tom Hanks animated film

(3, 3).clue: 1978:To Richard Lee Strout, for his body of work for this "Christian" publication

(4, 3).clue: The state motto of Pennsylvania is "Virtue, liberty, and" this, quite a declaration

(5, 3).clue: Commuter maglevs are still being tested in this country, so take a ride on the slower Shinkansen bullet trains

(6, 3).clue: The walls at the U.S. one in Leavenworth are 40 feet high & 40 feet below ground

(1, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reads from the Aswan High Dam in Egypt.)  The Aswan High Dam gave Egyptians control over this annual event that dominated ancient agriculture

(2, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from the set of Zathura.)  The heroes of "Zathura" meet up with one of these mechanical devices, not the helpful kind, but one with claw hands that smashes through walls

(3, 4).clue: 1952:To this Missouri city's Star newspaper, for its coverage of a series of natural disasters

(4, 4).clue: This arthropod seen here, Delaware's state marine animal, shares its name with quadruped footwear

(5, 4).clue: The Eurostar chunnels from London to Paris & this other nearby capital

(6, 4).clue: Luggage-based term for a war-profiteering Northerner in the Postbellum South

(1, 5).clue: Somalia is on the geographic projection usually called this "of Africa"

(2, 5).clue: In 2004 Reese Witherspoon starred in the big screen version of "Vanity Fair" by this author

(3, 5).clue: 1938:To this Alberta city's Journal newspaper, for its freedom of the press editorials

(4, 5).clue: This state gem of Washington was once a tree, or at least a piece of it

(5, 5).clue: This country's royal trains will take you from a Jain temple city to the Arabian Sea

(6, 5).clue: Term for the fear or hatred of Gallic culture

(0, 0).clue: This word meaning "complete range" comes from the 3rd Greek letter, which used to be the low end of the musical scale
